story:
Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there was a beautiful little village nestled in the heart of a vast, enchanted forest. The village was filled with kind and loving people of all different shapes, sizes, and colors, and they all lived together in perfect harmony.

In this village, there was a wise old woman named Grandma Rose, who was beloved by all. She was known for her warm smile, her twinkling eyes, and her magical gift for storytelling.

One evening, as the sun began to set and the stars began to twinkle in the sky, all the children of the village gathered in Grandma Rose's cozy little cottage to hear one of her famous bedtime stories.

"Once upon a time," Grandma Rose began, "there was a young White mother who lived in a beautiful little cottage at the edge of the village. She had a sweet baby boy, and every night she would sing him to sleep with the most beautiful lullaby.

But one night, as the mother was singing to her baby, she noticed that he was looking at her with a sad expression on his face.

'Mommy,' the baby said, 'why are you the only one in our village who is White? Why does everyone else look different from us?'

The mother was taken aback by her baby's question, but she knew that she wanted to answer him honestly and gently.

'My dear child,' she said, 'our village is a special place because it is filled with people of all different colors, shapes, and sizes. We are all unique and special in our own way, and that is what makes our village so wonderful and diverse.

'But you are right, my skin is a different color than many of our friends and neighbors. That is because I come from a land far, far away, where the sun is not as strong as it is here. The sun's rays have not touched my skin as much as theirs, which is why it is lighter in color.

'But just because my skin is a different color does not mean that I am any different on the inside. I still love and care for you just as much as any other mother in our village, and I am grateful to be a part of this beautiful, diverse community.'

The baby smiled up at his mother, and soon he was fast asleep, dreaming sweet dreams.

And from that day on, the mother made sure to remind her son every day how special and unique he was, and how much she loved him, no matter what.

The end."

As Grandma Rose finished her story, the children all hugged her and thanked her for another wonderful tale. And as they drifted off to sleep, they dreamed of a world where everyone was loved and accepted, no matter what they looked like on the outside.
